sources.data_found: Duke Compute Cluster (DCC) overview states: 980 GPUs total and includes 64 NVIDIA H200 GPUs.
DCC H200 partition (h200ea) is 6 nodes with 54 H200 GPUs.
DCC partitions GPU config includes P100: 2 GPUs/node across 10 nodes (and shows other GPU configs).
DCC 'gpuavail' example output shows configuration counts including gpu:p100:2 = 10 nodes and gpu:a6000:1 = 8 nodes; also shows 6000_ada configs totaling 28 GPUs.
Duke Computer Science cluster GPU totals include 16 A6000, 10 V100, 26 P100 (plus other GPUs not tallied here).
SoM HPC (RCC) page lists GPU partition: 1 node with 4 x NVIDIA L40S.
SoM HPC (PRCC) page lists GPU partition: 1 node with 8 x NVIDIA H200.

student_data.notes: Source is Duke CS '2024 Infographics Report' PDF. On the page labeled 'GRADUATE ENROLLMENT 2024-2025', it states '105 enrolled in PhD in CS' and '151 enrolled in MS in CS' (also separately lists 48 enrolled in MS in Economics & Computation, which is NOT counted in grad_cs_count). PDF also shows 'Last Updated: December 2024'. I did not find a Fall 2024 or AY 2024-25 undergrad CS *enrollment* headcount in this PDF; it only includes an undergraduate outcome metric ('448 CS majors graduated in 2024'), which I did not use as an enrollment count.

gpu_resources.notes:
Clusters included: (1) Duke Compute Cluster (DCC), (2) Duke CS Dept cluster, (3) SoM HPC RCC, (4) SoM HPC PRCC.

H200:
- DCC overview: total H200 GPUs = 64.
- PRCC: 1 node × 8 H200/node = 8.
=> H200 total = 64 + 8 = 72.

L40S:
- RCC: 1 node × 4 L40S/node = 4.

A6000:
- DCC (gpuavail config): gpu:a6000:1 has 8 nodes ⇒ 8 nodes × 1 = 8.
- CS cluster: 4 nodes × 4 A6000/node = 16.
=> A6000 total = 8 + 16 = 24.

V100:
- CS cluster: gpu-compute5 has 2 V100, gpu-compute6 has 4 V100, gpu-compute7 has 4 V100 ⇒ (1 node × 2) + (1 node × 4) + (1 node × 4) = 10.

P100:
- DCC (partitions): 10 nodes × 2 P100/node = 20.
- CS cluster: linux41-50 (10 nodes × 2 P100/node = 20) + gpu-compute4 (1 node × 4 = 4) + gpu-compute5 (1 node × 2 = 2) = 26.
=> P100 total = 20 + 26 = 46.

H100/A100:
- DCC documentation lists GPU types a100 (A100 80GB PCIe) and h100 (H100 NVL) as possible researcher-owned GPU types, but no node/GPU counts were found in publicly accessible Duke pages used above; therefore totals set to 0 here.

Other high-VRAM GPUs (not requested fields):
- DCC RTX 6000 Ada: 24 nodes × 1 + 1 node × 4 = 28.
- CS cluster RTX 6000 Pro: 20 total GPUs.

analysis_notes: Data collected via multi-query approach: separate student and GPU searches.
validation_notes: No changes made. All GPU resources appear to be locally owned. Student data is complete.
